title: 106_hr3458
content:
The "Child Abuse Prevention and Enforcement Act" includes a grant program. The Crime Identification Technology Act of 1998 is amended to enhance the capability of the criminal justice system to provide criminal history information to child welfare agencies for child protection. The Byrne Grant Program can now be used for child protection purposes. SEC. 103 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow the Byrne Grant Program funds to be used for enforcing child abuse and neglect laws, promoting programs to prevent child abuse, and supporting cooperative programs between law enforcement and media organizations for identifying criminal offenders. SEC. 104. CONDITIONAL ADJUSTMENT IN SET ASIDE FOR CHILD ABUSE VICTIMS UNDER THE VICTIMS OF CRIME ACT OF 1984. Section 1402(d)(2) of the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to allocate additional funds for grants under section 1404A based on the increase in the Fund deposit compared to fiscal year 1998, with a cap of $20,000,000. This adjustment aims to enhance support for victims of crime. The increase in funding provided shall operate regardless of any dollar limitation on the availability of the Crime Victims Fund established under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. TITLE II--JENNIFER'S LAW

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as ``Jennifer's Law''.

SEC. 202. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED.

The Attorney General is authorized to provide grant awards to States to improve the reporting of unidentified and missing persons.

SEC. 203. ELIGIBILITY. To be eligible for a grant award under this title, a State must submit an application with assurances to report deceased unidentified persons to law enforcement authorities, enter complete profiles in compliance with DOJ guidelines, and include necessary records like dental, DNA, x-rays, and fingerprints. To be eligible for a grant award, a State must report deceased unidentified persons to law enforcement, enter complete profiles in compliance with DOJ guidelines, and retain records until identification. A State receiving a grant under this title can use funds to improve reporting of unidentified persons. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2000-2002.
